name: Lord of Terror: Barbarian 20 / Druid 8 / Shifter 12
author: HipRedux

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Lord of Terror
Barbarian(20), Druid(8), Shifter(12), Any non-lawful neutral Human (TN recommended)
No, not Diablo this time.  This guy will kick Big D's butt back to the Abyss where it belongs.  Diablo couldn't freeze mobs of enemies in their tracks with a shout, avoid crits or do anywhere near the physical damage with his mangy claws.  Plus he couldn't have caused all the destruction he did without his mobs of minions shaking in their boots catering to his every whim.  This guy is an independent agent of Death!

Background

This build was suggested by one of our ECB mates, CosmicTomato, so I decided to fool with it since shifter has always been one of my favorite classes though not always feasible on all servers.  This request was bizarre enough and has so few similar builds listed I decided to refine one myself, test it and post it finished if it had potential.  It does.

The intended environment is The Aielund Saga.  That is primarily responsible for determining the skill set but only according to what I've read.  I rely on input from the veterans of that content to help tweak the build to best serve the needs that are presented therein.  Timing is everything!  I need a robust leveling sequence that is as synchronized with the demands of those modules as possible.

With shifter game play, I am most familiar with Risen Lord builds due to the lack of WIS commitment it requires. It makes the selection of that all-important tertiary class more open-ended.  But honestly, I have never considered a barbarian as a useful option.  It's not bad at all, if you are selective about the environment.  It will have its greatest advantage playing where ability caps are not easy to reach via items.  Otherwise, rage's value is neutralized and the commitment to all those barb levels amount to one goal only... accessing Terrifying Rage.  So... choose the right situation and this combination is fun and dominant to play.  The high Hit Dice of barb forms a cushion that buffers damage and the increased speed is a welcome benefit, especially in early levels.

Generally, the first few levels are the toughest since the DEX AB is only effective for range weapons.  No Weapon Finesse because it would be only a temporary, low-level fix for a STR-based melee focus in a feat-starved build.   DEX is the ability pumped because the preferred shape (RL) and secondary shape (Epic minotaur) both use the native DEX level and override both STR & CON.  Refer to my "Leveling Tips" section for a leg up on how I managed its progress in a customizable, scalable training environment.  I have not tried playing this on Aielund and most likely, never will.  I leave that to CosmicTomato and his partners in crime.

PROS
  • Typical shifter repertoire allows the toon to deal with many sorts of enemies by sheer shifting versatility rather than hunting down items to imbue the needed properties.
  • Risen Lord scythe criticals are one of the highest damage attacks, second only to a scythemaster crits or those alignment-dependent smiters.
  • A raging RL is nothing to sneeze at.  Even with the reduced AC, no opposed crits land and only bludgeoning attacks penetrate the damage immunities.
  • Terrifying Rage is lots of fun to have in the repertoire with all those stunned NPC standing there waiting to get chopped up. But I can't decide which form is more suitable.  The RL looks just plain evil and the Minotaur looks just plain hungry.  Maxed Intimidate sets the naked DC at 53 - 62.  55 - 64 with the effects of an Eagle pot or three.
  • 4 APR!  The one thing a barb tertiary does accomplish is 4 attacks per round with a nasty scythe... very atypical for shifter builds that usually integrate Tumble classes instead ending with 3 APR.
  • What doesn't an RL need to be concerned about?  Crits/sneaks (including WMs and DevCrit attacks), death magic, level/ability drain or negative energy damage, mind-control, paralysis, poison/disease and petrification (an appearance bug, but hey, we'll take it!).
  • Virtual Party fun.  Between the animal companion and a dire wolf/spider as party members, this RL will not get lonely and can play the hero by saving his pals from sure destruction.
CONS
  • Tough to level 1 through 7.  A designed Dexer without finesse has a hard time registering hits in melee.  A barb holding a sling or bow just looks silly but hits.  Thankfully, it doesn't last that long and the payoff makes it worth the suffering.
  • Pre-epic has few rage attempts.  The real raging starts after Risen Lord/Epic Minotaur is available at Level 24.  Then things get more manageable and fun.
  • What does an RL need to be concerned about?  Being turned, positive energy attacks (i.e. healing). High-STR bludgeoning attacks, all traps... yes, even Negative Traps (won't drain but will cause damage), IGMS, some Bigby's, some Epic Spells.
  • Epic Minotaur must be used vs. Clerics and high-level Pallies and for emergency healing.
  • Belt slot worthless.  This is not unique to this build but I am still registering it as a weakness nonetheless.  I use belts that increase strength while in native form just for carrying capacity.  Once shifted, carrying heavy loot is no longer a concern.
  • RL is impossible to heal without a friendly cleric (or a misguided enemy cleric) standing by casting negative energy spells on it.  The vampiric weapon helps a bit, though

Leveling Tips
Lvls 1 - 3: Combine barb movement with range weapon (sling/tower worked well for me) and kite targets.  Buy Cat pots, if available.
Lvls 4 - 7: Same as above except use brown bear as meat shield and add'l damage (use Fang buff).  Druid level 1-3 spell buffs now available.
Lvls 8 - 10: Brown bear (or Panther) shape 1x/day for 5 hrs.  Use Barkskin and Bull's Strength buffs.  Range attack with companion after shift times out.  Druid level 3 spells available now.
Lvl 11: Wyrmling. Combine Expertise with Wyrmling breath for AoE damage.  Use elementally-protected companion and summons 1-3 as needed.  Toggle wyrmling breath element types according to enemy resistance/immunity (eg. Greenie acid vs. shadow fiends). Always scout while invisible (pots) for effortless recon and cheese kills.  All wyrmies are True Seers so can recon stealthers well.

---- from this point on, weapon enhancements/props merge into shape ----

Lvl 13 - 23: Minotaur: Use enhanced companion as needed (Barkskin, Fang buff). Use taunts to increase attack. Use wyrmling breath attacks in expertise mode where highest AC is needed.  
Lvl 24-40: Risen Lord, Epic Minotaur:  Shift to Epic Minotaur when turning is threatened or to heal.  Companion/summons no longer needed.  Use whirlwind (carefully!) among dense flankers.  Use Minotaur's KD vs. IGMS/Bigby mages.  

Reference/Comments

Note: Attack and AC values reported on the Avatar Screen ignore the size modifier (which can be verified by combat debugging mode).  The following adjustments should be applied to the values show on the screen:  brown bear -1, wyrmling +1, minotaur -1, Risen Lord/panther - no change.  The same adjustment must be manually applied to stealth and detection values shown on the skill list screen (only detection applies for this build).

Note:  Haste and Divine Power show examples of free attacks. "Free attacks applied to users of creature weapons are implemented as additional attacks applied at end of the attack progression and continue the same BAB progression rate as the class dictates (-3 for monk, -5 for all other classes), ignoring the normal "full base attack" effect."   This mechanism effects all unarmed shapes like wyrmling or dragon. Example (hypothetical):  Minotaur and wyrmling both have a non-hasted AB of +20/+15/+10/+5.  The shifter unmorphs, equips Boots of Speed and attacks with both shapes.  The minotaur's revised AB is now +20/+15/+10/+5/+20.  The wymling's is +20/+15/+10/+5/+0.

Note:  One caution I will pass on because I succumbed myself by accident... Be CERTAIN to unmorph before leveling up, else assigning skill points may not go as planned for some reason.  Must have something to do with appearance but I lost some skill points along the way until I started paying closer attention.  The schedule listed in this build should work fine as long as your toon obeys this rule.

Comment
Brb/Dru/Shf combo and AC:  Typically, a Tumble class like Monk or Rogue would be used for the tertiary.  This change is evidenced by the -4 Tumble AC less than more "typical" shifter builds.  With full Tumble, a +5 deflection AC merge and Barkskin pre-buff, a hasted RL would approach the more typical 55+ AC range.  In this build, without any further enhancements, like reaching the DEX cap (+6 AC), the build will fall in the 51+ AC range.

Sweet! I'm definitely going to give this a try as soon as I can. Luckily, you're given two (one of which is a cleric, funnily enough) companions right at the start of the first chapter of Aielund, which finishes at about level 7-8, so the early levelling won't be a huge problem at least. Once I'm done, I'll get back to you with my own thoughts.

Quick question about the AC right at the end. In your last comment, when you calculate the AC in the build "without further enhancements", are you taking into account the merged deflection AC already? The phrasing confused me a little bit.

You know, off the top of my head, I can't think of many cleric builds that choose to focus on pumping CHA, so the max HD of the turn would be slightly lower. Mostly they're either casters (which I would still have to watch out for) or self-buffers (maybe less so?), which I tend to regard as the slightly scarier variant. Pallys would also still be an issue. Still a glimmer of hope at least. That said, because I've not played online at all, I could be completely misrepresenting the danger they pose, which is considerable even without the turning. I haven't played far enough into Aielund to see any clerics, but it should prove interesting if I do encounter any.

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
CosmicTomato wrote:
Sweet! I'm definitely going to give this a try as soon as I can. Luckily, you're given two (one of which is a cleric, funnily enough) companions right at the start of the first chapter of Aielund, which finishes at about level 7-8, so the early levelling won't be a huge problem at least. Once I'm done, I'll get back to you with my own thoughts.
 
Too bad there isn't a friendly cleric available to inflict your RL in the later stages of the series.  Then again, hench control (like choosing and executing specific spells during combat) is usually not very good without TonyK's AI installed so the option may be a moot point anyway.  But a capable party member will certainly make the going much easier.  Don't dismiss the brown bear companion.  When it is buffed with fang and force-fed some ability pots, it stands up pretty well and the infinite healing/feeding keeps it viable for a long time.
Quick question about the AC right at the end. In your last comment, when you calculate the AC in the build "without further enhancements", are you taking into account the merged deflection AC already? The phrasing confused me a little bit.
I'll try to rewrite that to be less ambiguous.  Tx for the input.

Yes. I am assuming that it isn't a low-magic environment.  If it is, the lofty AC won't be necessary because the enemies generally won't have an AB worthy enough to hit any AC over 35-ish and Undead Shape banned.  Chances are, during your travels, you will encounter some gear item that has a +5 bonus.  It could be the armor (or robe), a shield (matters not what size), a cloak, a pair of dodge boots (no UMD or monk in this build, though), perhaps one of those +5 natural ammies or some ring of protection (again, deflection). Any of those will provide that expected +5 deflection for the total merge.  Just beware that the AC bonus types never stack and it should be easy to glean +5 from common items.

The additional AC enhancements I was referring to are mainly items to raise DEX to the cap (+12, i.e. +6 modifier) and permahaste.  I like to use some weapon of speed, if one exists, rather than clogging the boot slot with permahaste since there are usually many unusual enhancments on boots. The build covers just about every class weapon imaginable so the choice is wide.  Make sure to use a one-hand weapon, though.  Any range weapons like darts will not merge.

So, potentially you could add another +10 to the level I described for any of the armed forms and that means breaching the 60 AC barrier.  It's actually quite overpowering in all but the highest magic environments.

If, for example, there is any item that bestows immunity to evocation school (but not on a belt), then this RL would be near invincible.  But immunities are rare in mid-magic content for good reason.  Too hard to balance challenge.
You know, off the top of my head, I can't think of many cleric builds that choose to focus on pumping CHA, so the max HD of the turn would be slightly lower. Mostly they're either casters (which I would still have to watch out for) or self-buffers (maybe less so?), which I tend to regard as the slightly scarier variant. Pallys would also still be an issue. Still a glimmer of hope at least. That said, because I've not played online at all, I could be completely misrepresenting the danger they pose, which is considerable even without the turning. I haven't played far enough into Aielund to see any clerics, but it should prove interesting if I do encounter any.
CHA is used mainly to slightly increase the number of creatures turned by adding all their class HD.  It is also used to modify the turn check, but that is just a d20 roll so that means you might escape a few attempts but when facing a mob of clerics, the odds are in their favor.  Keep in mind that the RL's HD for that calculation is the shifter level, not the toon level.  That would be the grand total of 11 (or 12 near the end of the build). It works the same way for the opposed cleric.  It's the class level that is used to determine HD for the turning calculation, not the character level.  And no help from turn resistance to boot.  That's 50-50 chance to increase the 2d6 up to +4.  Add the cleric's class level onto that and it gets pretty ugly. Who knows if the designer assigned sun domain to them as well?  Whether they have high CHA or not has little effect on the outcome in the case of a low-level shifter (meaning Shf 30 would be the highest class HD possible).

Short story (sorta)...

The first attempt I made testing a working RL was with the SoU-HotU expansions because I knew that plan could be accomplished within 28 levels easily.  I arranged a fast RL (Level 21) and was cruising through HotU so easily as an RL I thought I had corrupted the toon with some sort of godly skin somehow. It was so easy! (And I always play on "Very Difficult" setting to better reflect server play.)  Well, yes, easy... until that final battle of Chapter 2 where around 20 duergar clerics stood poised outside the gate, up to that point just healing their wounded comrades and ignoring my toon's presence.   The RL killing machine rushed out to bless them in that special way it had become accustomed to up to that point (sharp blade at the end of pole seeking heads... hehehe) and... WHAAA? It was turned before it got more than 2 steps through the gate and roamed like a lost puppy getting pummeled to death with fire attacks without recourse.  All I could see was all the lost XP I had been anticipating for those juicy duergar kills.  Lesson learned and noted.  "RL shall henceforward avoid clerics like the plague."  Since then, my RLs have never been turned and the minotaur has been christening its greataxe with fresh blood.

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
One relatively minor point about the early epic levels that keen observers may have noticed...

At level 22 I had a choice to use either insert another druid level for a Spellcraft dump and add'l level 2 and 3 spell slots or the additional rage attempt plus some HP.  Since I had been struggling trying to exist with the paltry 2 attempts up to that point, I wanted to have 3x/day ready for the RL.  This is a rage-intensive build, right?

That was a personal choice weighing the saves/slots vs. rage attempts so it could perceivably be changed but, if so, a redo of the skill allotment would be needed for epic levels.  I'll leave that task for those who are so inclined.  From my experience, there are so few spells that permit a save that can affect the RL, higher saves in early epic has little effect on the playability. And the druid buffs are really only frosting on the cake, if you follow my drift.

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Nah.  A drastic measure like Mass Harm is not needed.  All the Inflict spells do the same and, if going Evil domain, the saviour spell, NEBurst which will drain STR at the same time along with NERay for occasional spot healing.  All negative energy spells mentioned can be empowered since they are dice rolls.  Restoring an RL's HP is rare to begin with... ultra AC, crit immunity and all the other immunities.  It's quite easy to implement actually.  We do it on WoG and HG when I am fortunate enough to find a cleric logged willing to party.  Now, Evil ones... that's quite rare unless you convince a partymate to build that way explicitly for duo coop.

My advice to other party members who are attempting to coop with an RL up close and personal: Steer clear!... and let it do what it was designed to do...  TANK!  Else that head being lopped off by the scythe could be an innocent bystander looking for an autograph.
